data.title: Update Lidgren to REV#391
Android RenderOnUIThread and Multiple Context Support
data.body:
With the Upgrade to OpenTK-1 on android we now have the capability to make use of the RenderOnUIThread support in the AndroidGameView. When set to false the AndroidGameView will NOT create the context on the UI thread but on the background render thread that it uses to do the tick. This has a bonus in that is saves a call to SyncContext.Post to marshal the OnRender call to the UI thread, this can save up to 100ms per tick and is the main cause to the occasional stutter when rendering.

The problem is at the moment we can't use this property because the Android implementation makes various assumptions about which thread its running on. When RenderOnUIThread is set to false we get allot of Bad Context errors and nothing is rendered.

"someone" needs to look into fixing this up ;) (probably me or @danzel (but I have my hands full with Mac Content Pipeline stuff atm â€¦  ))

In additon, with the latest OpenTK-1 the ability to use multiple contexts is available. This could be used for background loading of textures etc. However there is a caveat, only one context can be active at a time on android, so some kind of locking mechanism will need to be used. Not sure its worth the effort as the current system works quite well. 

see https://github.com/xamarin/monodroid-samples/tree/master/GLSharedContext20

data.body:
id like to offer a alternate suggestion to #3204 ... (this is basically a modification of that suggestion)
that provides a solution to that
yet at the same time a distinctly separate feature request
that is also highly indie-friendly and makes sense
...
including a default sprite-font class with a default loading method
that will auto load a default installer-included spritefont when called

...

data.title: Use indexed for loop for nested shared resources
data.body:
I am playing around with the content pipeline, trying to convert something I wrote with XNA to it. One of the resources I wrote an importer/processor for calls `WriteSharedResource()` inside its `Write()`. I don't know if that's good or bad but it worked with XNA. With MonoGame it creates an exception since the list of `sharedResources` gets modified inside a loop.

Converting to a simple indexed loop seems to make it work. I don't know much about how to test this part MonoGame beyond what my own code was able to execute.

I'm also fairly new to C# so if there's some better solution don't hestitate to suggest it. Still learning!

data.title: Center OpenTK game window when it is resized to mimic the behavior of WinFormsGameWindow
Game.OnExiting is called too late when closing with close window button
data.body:
The problem is that the Game does not call OnExiting for a while after clicking the close button of the window with the mouse. We use the OnExiting method to keep track of the state of the game, but it is not useful for this purpose because it has a delay. Not being able to know whether game is exiting causes crashes because we get the mouse state every update. 

This is consistently reproduceable with MonoGame 3.2 OpenGL on a Windows 8.1 Pro 64bit desktop.

A nice way to handle this would be to suspend closing the window until things have cleaned up. Unfortunately GameWindow does not provide functionality to cancel closing of the window.

data.title: TouchPanel exception on WP8
data.body:
Another (more critical) bug that happens sometimes for #3200:
1. WP8 reports pressed. MonoGame stores the touch.
2. Game starts to call GetState that starts to call `AgeTouches(_touchState);`...
3. WP8 reports released. MonoGame removes touch in `ApplyTouch`.
4. Game continues to loop in the list of states, where the touch has been removed.

    New touch: Touch id:2 state:Released position:{{X:139,5 Y:274,5}} pressure:0 prevState:Invalid prevPosition:{{X:0 Y:0}} previousPressure:0

data.title: Quick touch gets stuck on WP8 (Case 2)
data.body:
Here is case 2 for #3200:
1. WP8 reports pressed. MonoGame stores the touch.
2. WP8 reports released. MonoGame receives the touch and starts updating it...
3. Game starts to call GetState, which ages the touch.
4. MonoGame continues with its own copy of the touch that is still in Pressed state. `SameFrameReleased` is set to true in `UpdateState`.
5. Game receives the Pressed touch.

No further touches are sent by TouchPanel, as it "lied" about the pressed state and did not resolve the lie by sending the released state in the next frame. Resolving the lie was the job of `AgeState`, but that was not called because the touch was removed in the next `GetState` call:

```
//If a touch was pressed and released in a previous frame and the user didn't ask about it then trash it.
if (touch.SameFrameReleased && touch.Timestamp < CurrentTimestamp && touch.State == TouchLocationState.Pressed)
```

```
[WP8] Pressed 1 {{X:480 Y:727,5}}
[WP8] Released 1 {{X:480 Y:727,5}}
[MonoGame] UpdateState
   New touch: Touch id:2 state:Released position:{{X:480 Y:727,5}} pressure:0 prevState:Invalid prevPosition:{{X:0 Y:0}} previousPressure:0
   Old touch: Touch id:2 state:Moved position:{{X:480 Y:727,5}} pressure:0 prevState:Invalid prevPosition:{{X:0 Y:0}} previousPressure:0
[MonoGame] Lie that we are pressed for now
   Updated touch: Touch id:2 state:Pressed position:{{X:480 Y:727,5}} pressure:0 prevState:Pressed prevPosition:{{X:480 Y:727,5}} previousPressure:0
[MonoGame] GetState returned Touch id:2 state:Pressed position:{{X:480 Y:727,5}} pressure:0 prevState:Invalid prevPosition:{{X:0 Y:0}} previousPressure:0
```

data.title: Quick touch gets stuck on WP8 (Case 1)
data.body:
Here is case 1 for #3200:

This is a concurrency issue.
1. WP8 reports pressed. MonoGame stores the touch.
2. WP8 reports released. MonoGame starts to receive the touch...
3. Game starts to call GetState, which ages the touch still in Pressed state. (This is why the touch that is removed is in the Moved state, not Pressed)
4. MonoGame continues and removes the touch because the timestamp of the two touches are not the same because touches are pushed and not pulled at update.
   Since the touch was removed, MonoGame does not report anything about the touch anymore (GetState will return an empty list) and it will appear stuck in Pressed to the game.

```
[WP8] Pressed 1 {{X:447 Y:675}}
[WP8] Released 1 {{X:447 Y:675}}
[MonoGame] Touch remove
   New touch: Touch id:2 state:Released position:{{X:447 Y:675}} pressure:0 prevState:Invalid prevPosition:{{X:0 Y:0}} previousPressure:0
   Old touch: Touch id:2 state:Moved position:{{X:447 Y:675}} pressure:0 prevState:Invalid prevPosition:{{X:0 Y:0}} previousPressure:0
[MonoGame] GetState returned Touch id:2 state:Pressed position:{{X:447 Y:675}} pressure:0 prevState:Invalid prevPosition:{{X:0 Y:0}} previousPressure:0
```
